Award.AwardTitle: Research Study of the LSAMP Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) has a diverse portfolio of programs geared toward having broader societal impacts in terms of advancing discovery and knowledge by promoting education in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM); broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM; enhancing infrastructure for research and education through collaborations between institutions, industry, and others; and disseminating knowledge. The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Program and the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) fit perfectly within these goals, as do the activities proposed in this project. LSAMP aims to broaden STEM participation by building collaborations to increase the representation of minority students receiving STEM degrees and pursuing graduate study. The evidence and knowledge generated by this study will help NSF make programmatic decisions and should benefit LSAMP and similar programs. First, this study will help NSF determine the extent to which today's LSAMP Program aligns with current NSF priorities. Second, by comparing graduation data from the LSAMP monitoring data system and the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC), this project will gauge the quality and usefulness of estimates generated from data collected through the monitoring data system. This will help LSAMP provide guidance to grantees and improve its approach to data collection. Last, the subgroup analysis of LSAMP-BD will help inform NSF's decisions and build the knowledge base, given the lack of rigorous evidence on whether fellowships help increase the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. The study's findings may also have an impact beyond NSF,particularly in agencies and foundations working to build and diversify the STEM workforce by providing evidence on the effectiveness of similar programs and guidance on using monitoring data systems and implementing reporting requirements for grantees.

This study will expand on earlier evaluations of LSAMP and LSAMP-BD. It includes three distinct components. First, the LSAMP longitudinal data analysis will focus on the evolution and characteristics of the LSAMP Program over time, including activities offered and characteristics of the alliances, institutions, faculty, and students. This mostly descriptive and time-series analysis will draw on population data from the LSAMP monitoring data system. The second evaluation component will focus on verifying the quality of graduation data and the accuracy of these data among LSAMP Program participants. This will involve comparing graduation outcomes reported by institutions through the LSAMP monitoring data system with those reported to the NSC. This analysis will be based on a stratified random sample of LSAMP participants and will rely on standard t- and chi-squared tests to estimate significant differences between estimates generated from the two data sources. The third evaluation component, the BD subgroup impact analyses, will build on the recent BD evaluation by analyzing impacts by gender and prior preparation for graduate-level studies. Impacts will be estimated by measuring the (regression-adjusted) difference in average outcomes for the participant group (those receiving the BD fellowship) versus a matched comparison group (those not offered the fellowship and matched using propensity-score matching techniques). These impacts will be estimated using linear probability models to model the probability of reaching key milestones on the path to a Ph.D., including graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF’s mission is not only to promote advances across science and engineering fields, but also to prepare the workforce of the future in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). NSF seeks to achieve this human resource development aspect of its mission by investing in programs to train the workforce in STEM. Other federal government agencies also contribute to this goal by investing in training scientists in STEM areas aligned with their mission. Our literature review found that 30 programs across 13 government agencies offer support for graduate training—as do many private foundations—yet these efforts have rarely been studied rigorously. This study therefore contributes knowledge that is useful not only to NSF regarding one of its longest standing human capital development programs—the Louis Stokes Alliances for Participation (LSAMP)—but also to other government agencies and philanthropies that support similar efforts and seek to develop data systems to monitor participation and outcomes.

This study produced: (1) a longitudinal, descriptive analysis of the characteristics of the LSAMP program, which has been supporting undergraduate students since its inception in 1991; (2) an analysis of the impact of support provided for master’s and doctoral students—overall and by subgroups of interest; and (3) an analysis of the LSAMP monitoring data system in terms of data quality. The data for this study came from 4 data sources: the LSAMP and LSAMP-Bridge to the Doctorate (LSAMP-BD) monitoring data systems (for information on participants), the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS, for institutional characteristics), and the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC, for educational outcomes).

Descriptive analyses of LSAMP data between 1991 and 2016 show:

  • Among institutions: Growth over time (from 6 alliances with nearly 100 institutions in 1991 to 46 alliances with over 500 institutions by 2016); longevity in participation (alliances and institutions joined and left the program over time, with a stable group participating for over 20 years); increasing participation of two-year colleges and Hispanic-serving institutions in alliances (with declining participation of HBCUs); and also increasing representation of non-academic partners over time, such as federal laboratories.
  • Among students: The vast majority of participants are from groups underrepresented in STEM (as intended by the program), with the share of students declaring more than one race/ethnicity growing over time. Although overall participation by gender has been similar over time, gender gaps persist for Hispanics. Women’s participation in the program, lowest in engineering and computer science, is declining in computer science.
  • Among activities: Institutions (both 2- and 4-year colleges) are offering more research opportunities to students. Student participation in research increased through 2010 and declined in recent years. Students who participate in research activities have higher grade point averages than those who do not, on average.

In 2003, the BD component of the program was created to support the first 2 years of graduate study among former LSAMP participants, with the expectation that students would continue on to pursue a Ph.D. Our impact analyses of participation in LSAMP-BD was based on a comparison of students funded through the program and a matched comparison group of students not funded through the program. Findings indicate that:

  • Nearly 90 percent of BD participants completed graduate degrees.
  • BD has an overall positive impact on graduate degree attainment—as it increases the likelihood of completing a master’s degree among students pursuing doctoral degrees and of completing a doctoral degree among students who receive the fellowship to pursue a master’s degree. BD has a negative impact on Ph.D. completion among students initially pursuing a Ph.D. (students tend to exit with a master’s degree).
  • BD impacts generally do not vary for different groups students, on average. Specifically, program impacts (on master’s or Ph.D. attainment) do not vary by sex, achievement on the GRE, career trajectory (started at a 2-year college or had a master’s degree already) or institution type (minority-serving or not). Findings suggest higher impacts on graduate degree attainment among students with lower incoming GPA (compared to those with higher incoming GPA, on average).          

Last, our data quality assessment provides lessons regarding how best to design and collect monitoring data to enhance data quality and reduce respondent burden. For example, design decisions such as allowing institutions to re-assign the same ID numbers to new cohorts of students jeopardize our ability to track student progress. In contrast, the use of NSC data provides a viable alternative to collecting enrollment and graduation outcomes from institutions. NSC provides more complete information for student educational outcomes beyond the institutions participating in the program, is less costly (than collecting data directly from institutions’ administrative records), faster (can be obtained within a couple of weeks), and with zero burden on respondents. However, high data quality—and in particular date of birth—are needed to obtain a high match rate to the NSC.
